item.title: Photos: How torn pictures and trusted herbs create healing in Colombia
item.description: Conflict has sewn trauma in the western region of Colombia. Doctors Without Borders is working with local healers and health care professionals to come up with ways to help heal the psychic wounds.

item.title: Israel vows to intensify attacks after Iranian missile hits major hospital
item.description: Officials said they were still assessing "extensive damage" at a major hospital in southern Israel after it was struck by an Iranian missile early Thursday.

item.description: People spend a lot of time outside during hot weather. Whether you're going to the beach, walking your dog or working your shift as a lifeguard, try these 7 proven ways to stay cool and prevent heat-related illness while outside.

item.title: Inside a school that's working to fix the U.S. shortage of air traffic controllers
item.description: Facing a severe shortage, the FAA is racing to hire thousands of air traffic controllers. But training them can take years. We visit a school in Florida that's trying to get them on the job faster.

item.title: SpaceX rocket being tested in Texas explodes, but no injuries reported
item.description: A SpaceX rocket being tested in Texas exploded Wednesday night, sending a dramatic fireball high into the sky. The company said the Starship "experienced a major anomaly."

item.title: Hurricane Erick makes landfall in western Mexico as a Category 3 storm
item.description: Hurricane Erick made landfall in Mexico's western state of Oaxaca early Thursday. The storm was downgraded slightly before making landfall, from a powerful Category 4 to a Category 3.

item.title: U.S. resumes visas for foreign students but demands access to social media accounts
item.description: The U.S. State Department said it is restarting the process for foreigners applying for student visas but all applicants will now be required to unlock their social media accounts for review.
